Summary Research Associate with extensive experience in various facets of material and membrane research and development. Contributed novel ideas to the field of templated ordered mesoporous silica materials and membranes which have applications in low-k dielectrics, catalysis, molecular sieving etc.  
 
Work has been presented in several national and international conferences. Publications include peer reviewed journal articles and a book chapter published by Elsevier. 
 
Proficient in several material characterization techniques (including TEM, SEM, XRD) and design of experiments (DOE). Expertise in separation processes involving inorganic membranes.  
 
Strong analytical problem solving skills, hands-on experience with equipment building/troubleshooting and laboratory procedures.  
 
Demonstrated teamwork and leadership abilities, having held key office positions in nonprofit organizations. Specialties:Nano-materials, membranes and thin films synthesis and characterization Experience Yield Engineer IMO Intel Corporation April 2014  – Present (1 year 5 months) Portland, Oregon Area Yield Engineer Intel Corporation January 2012  –  March 2014  (2 years 3 months) Albuquerque, New Mexico Area Research Associate/Student (PhD) Arizona State University August 2005  –  May 2011  (5 years 10 months) ***Research Associate with Prof. Jerry Lin at the Membrane and Energy Laboratory*** 
 
Developed technique to synthesize and characterized the first defect free 2.5 nm oriented ordered silica (SBA-3) membranes on polymer supports.  
 
Enhanced MCM-48 membrane performance by developing a new Al-MCM-48 membrane (pore size 2.5 nm) to achieve a 10 fold improvement in water vapor/oxygen separation factor.  
 
Established techniques to synthesize multilayer mesoporous and macroporous ordered membranes. 
 
Developed and optimized new defect sealing technique for silica membranes. 
 
Identified and optimized factors that influence silica fiber synthesis to enhance fundamental understanding of the formation process in ordered mesoporous silica materials by templated sol-gel technique. 
 
Acquired proficiency in TEM, XRD, SEM, EDS, Nitrogen Porosimetry, TGA-DSC, GC/TCD, FTIR, Permeation Apparatuses, MATLAB, gPROMS, C, Origin, Word Processing (Word, Excel, Powerpoint etc). 
 
Managed and established hazardous waste disposal policies in the Membrane and Energy Laboratory.  
 
Responsible for mentoring new students, equipment maintenance and chemical inventory Project Assistant Indian Institute of Science August 2004  –  July 2005  (1 year) *** Project Assistant with Prof. Jayant Modak *** 
 
Worked on modeling and computer simulation of fermentation processes. 
 
Developed models considering both kinetic and transport phenomena occurring in the process which were verified with the existing steady state and dynamic plant data from Lupin Pharmaceuticals. 
 
Models were then used in training simulators, predictive control strategies, inferential estimation of product qualities, data reconciliation, parameter estimation and optimization. 
 
Performed data analysis using MATLAB; gPROMS was used as a modeling, simulation and optimization tool. 
 
This project was done in collaboration with Asea Brown Boveri Limited (ABB). Undergraduate Team lead AstraZeneca Pharma India Pvt. Limit March 2004  –  June 2004  (4 months) Worked at AstraZeneca Pharma India Pvt. Limit, Bangalore India.  
 
Estimated the solvent loss during the production of prostaglandin, a maternal healthcare drug. 
 
Designed a gaseous waste incinerator for the destruction of the solvent vapors. Labview Mechanical Testing AFM Design of Experiments See 11+     See less Education University of Florida Ph. D.,  Mechanical Engineering 2010  – 2013 The goal of my Ph. D. research is to develop a scanning probe microscopy (SPM) cantilever with an integrated electrothermally actuated microgripper for automated tool-tip exchange. By automating the probe-tip exchange process, my research addresses the critical issues of low throughput, tip wear, chemical cross contamination of the tip, and scalability – all of which act to decrease the quality, reliability, and efficiency of SPM-based nanofabrication. The new system is a nanoscale analog of macroscale computer numerical control (CNC) manufacturing machines that have the ability for fully automated rapid tool changes without operator interruption. The system can be used (i) rapid prototyping of nanoelectronics and nano-electro-mechanical-systems (NEMS), (ii) creation of hybrid organic and inorganic nanostructures, and (iii) realization of a low-cost “desktop nanofactory”. Experience PTD Yield Engineer Intel Corporation March 2014  – Present (1 year 6 months) Portland, Oregon Area Graduate Research Assistant University of Maryland September 2008  –  February 2014  (5 years 6 months) • Currently leading an experiment to generate EUV/soft X-ray high harmonics by guiding high intensity laser pulse in a preformed plasma waveguide 
• Studied in the interaction of intense laser with matters: 
a. Acceleration of electrons up to 100MeV in 1cm by quasi-phase matched condition with copropagating laser field in corrugated plasma waveguide 
b. μm-scale plasma manipulation to create precisely defined density modulated plasma waveguide 
c. Multiple techniques for making structured plasma waveguides capable of guiding ultra-intense laser pulses  
d. Soft X-ray/ extreme ultraviolet generation (2 ~ 40 nm) in laser-produced plasmas arising from the interaction between ultra-intense femtosecond laser pulses and clustered gas targets in a vacuum  
• Designed optical set-up and diagnosis tools for various experiments 
• Operated and maintained the-state-of-the-art 25TW Ti:Sapphire laser system 
• Fabricated transmissive ring gratings on optically flat fused silica windows by photolithography and reactive ion etching technique. 
• Designed and developed a single shot second harmonic autocorrelator, electron spectrometer, Thomson parabola spectrometer, radial polarizer for high intensity laser pulse 
• Developed simulation softwares: Fresnel diffraction calculation, grating shape designing tool,  
• Set up various simulation environments in a Particle-In-Cell code, “TurboWAVE”, for direct laser acceleration in corrugated plasma waveguide, relativistic laser field guiding in plasma waveguide, cluster ionization studies.
